case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Kerala and Coimbatore v. Helen Rubber Industries, Ltd., Kottayam

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 466 of 1960 filed by Commissioner of Income Tax.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 466 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1958 of the Kerala High Court in I. T. No. 2 of 1956

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 31, 1958 of Kerala High Court in I.T. No. 2 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1958 of the Kerala High Court in I. T. No. 2 of 1956  K . N. Rajagopal Sastri and P. D. Menon, for appellant. The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Kerala High Court answered question in favour of respondent Helen Rubber Industries Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: by which the High Court answered in favour of the respondent  Helen Rubber Industries, Ltd., Kottayam  the following question Whether under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act the petitioner is entitled to carry forward the loss for a period of six years

facts.text: Helen Rubber Industries Ltd. incorporated in former State of Travancore with registered office at Kottayam.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Helen Rubber Industries, Ltd. is a Company, which was incorporated in the former State of Travancore with its registered office at Kottayam.

facts.text: In 1941, assessee Company granted lease of factory for 15 years.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1941, the assessee Company granted a lease of the factory to certain persons for a period of 15 years.

facts.text: From 1941, rent and royalty from lessees were only source of income.

anchor.surface_text: From that year, the rent and royalty received from the lessees were the only source of income. Disputes having arisen, the lessees suspended payment from June 1946.

facts.text: Lessees suspended payment from June 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes having arisen, the lessees suspended payment from June 1946. Litigation followed but the dispute was settled by the assessee Company receiving Rs. 23,000/- odd in full satisfaction.

facts.text: Dispute settled by assessee receiving Rs. 23,000 odd.

anchor.surface_text: Litigation followed but the dispute was settled by the assessee Company receiving Rs. 23,000/- odd in full satisfaction. With the details of these disputes and their settlement, we are number companycerned.

facts.text: Assessee Company's year of account is the calendar year.

anchor.surface_text: The year of account of the assessee Company is the Calendar year. Before the extension of the Indian Income-tax Act, there was in force in Travancore State, the Travancore Income-tax Act,

facts.text: Travancore Income-tax Act XXIII of 1121 M.E. came into force on August 17, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: there was in force in Travancore State, the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121 M. E.  Act XXIII of 1121 M. E. , which came into force on the first day of Chingom 1122 E.  August 17, 1946 .

facts.text: Assessment year under Travancore Act ended on August 16, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year under the Travancore Act ended on the last day of Karkadakom, which companyresponds to August 16, 1947.

facts.text: Assessee declared losses in account years 1946, 1947, 1948 totaling Rs. 13241-9-3.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company declared losses in the account years, 1946, 1947 and 1948. These losses, together with the dates of the account years and the assessment years are tabulated below- Year of account Year of assessment. Loss -------------------------------------------------- -- 1946 1-1-1946 to 1123 M. E.  17-8-1947 Rs. 4031-10-0 31-12-1946  to 16-8-1948

facts.text: Loss for 1946 account year: Rs. 4031-10-0.
Dispute about right to carry forward 1946 loss to assessment year 1951-52 (account year 1950).

anchor.surface_text: The dispute in this case is about the right of the assessee Company to carry forward the loss of the year 1946 under the provisions of the Travancore Act read with s. 24 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held 1946 loss could not be carried forward, lapsed after two years under s.32 Travancore Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that the loss of the year 1946 companyld number be carried forward to that year, since it had lapsed after two years under s. 32 of the Travancore Act,

facts.text: ITO order confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyfirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal declined to state case, High Court called for statement under s.66(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was moved for a case, but declined to state one but the High Court called for a statement of the case under s. 66 2

facts.text: Indian Income-tax Act extended to Travancore-Cochin by s.3 Indian Finance Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Income-tax Act was extended to Travancore-Cochin by s. 3 of the Indian Finance Act, 1950.

facts.text: Assessment for 1951-52 made under Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment for the year, 1951- 52, was thus made on the assessee Company under the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Assessee Company not represented at hearing before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company was number represented at the hearing before this Court.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on January 16, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 16.-The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-The Commissioner of Income Tax, Kerala and Coimbatore, has filed this appeal

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal thus succeeds, and is allowed.

facts.text: Loss of 1946 could be carried forward only for two years under Travancore Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Travancore Act laid down, inter alia, that a loss arising in the previous year for the assessment for the year ending on the last day of Karkadakom, 1123, companyld be carried forward for two years.

facts.text: High Court certificate granted under s.66A of Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act the petitioner is entitled to carry forward the loss for a period of six years notwithstanding the fact that during the period when the loss had occurred, the law applicable was the Travancore Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, with all due respect, was number right in thinking that the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 was meant to enlarge the rights of the new assessees brought within the reach of the Indian Income-tax law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ew assessees brought within the reach of the Indian Income-tax law. The intention of the law was to make a dividing line between those previous years

arguments.court_reasoning: Intention to make dividing line between prior law previous years and Indian Act previous years; rights neither enlarged nor curtailed

arguments.claim: As per Chagla CJ in Indore Malwa United Mills v CIT, integration preserves only the right under state law to carry forward losses

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by Chagla, C.J. in the Indore Malwa United Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax  1 . the only right integration has given to an assessee is the right companytained in clauses  sic  3 of the  Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950

holdings.text: The law to apply to the loss of any previous year prior to the previous year for the assessment for the year ending on the 31st day of March, 1950 was the law in force in a Part B State (the Travancore Act).

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 3 of that order provided Carry-forward and set off of previous losses-where in any previous year prior to the previous year for the assessment for the year ending on the 31st day of March 1950, an assessee has sustained a loss of profits or gains in any business,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual emphasis on 'critical words' in para 3 of Removal of Difficulties Order requiring same manner, extent, and period as under continuing state law.

holdings.text: A loss arising in the previous year for the assessment for the year ending on the last day of Karkadakom, 1123, could be carried forward for two years under the Travancore Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Travancore Act laid down, inter alia, that a loss arising in the previous year for the assessment for the year ending on the last day of Karkadakom, 1123, could be carried forward for two years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.32 Travancore Act reproduces Indian IT Act s.24(2) with dates adapted to Travancore calendar commencement on 17 August 1946.

holdings.text: The 1946 loss (account year 1-1-1946 to 31-12-1946, assessment year 17-8-1947 to 16-8-1948) could be carried forward only to assessment year up to 16-8-1950 and not to 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year for 1123, M.E. covered the period, 17-8-1947 to 16-8-1948, and the previous year of the assessee Company relative to that assessment year was 1-1-1946 to 31-12-1946. The loss of the Calendar year, 1946 could be carried forward to the Calendar years, 1947 and 1948

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precise matching of account year to Travancore assessment year under s.32; two-year limit expires before 1951-52.

holdings.text: The Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 was not meant to enlarge the rights of assessees; it preserved state law rights without enlargement or curtailment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, with all due respect, was not right in thinking that the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 was meant to enlarge the rights of the new assessees brought within the reach of the Indian Income-tax law. The intention of the law was to make a dividing line

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading to draw line between pre- and post-extension periods; confirmed by precedent in Indore Malwa United Mills v CIT.

precedents.cited_proposition: the only right the Act has given to an assessee is the right contained in clause 3 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 and that right is that if the law of his own State permitted him to carry forward the losses, then that right is preserved under the Indian Income-tax Act
